subject: Nutrition
title: Hypervitaminosis A
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Hypervitaminosis A.

hook.text: In 1913, two Antarctic explorers ate their sled dogs' livers and suffered violent illness for weeks.

buildup.text: Hypervitaminosis A occurs when the vitamin accumulates to toxic levels in the liver.

discovery.text: Symptoms include nausea, blurred vision, bone pain, and in severe cases, liver failure and death.

twist.text: Chronic low-level overdose from supplements is more common than acute poisoningâ€”and harder to detect.

climax.text: Beta-carotene from plants converts to vitamin A only as needed, making food sources safe to eat freely.

punchline.text: Carrots are safe. Supplements need caution.

quiz.question: Why is beta-carotene from plants safer than vitamin A supplements?
options: Your body converts only what it needs
